column2: P5JS - Variables and random()!
What you'll do
In part 2 of this activity, you'll use variables with random() to generate random colors!
Welcome back, {{user_name}}! I'm super excited to show you how to create random colors using variables!
Let's start up the online editor for p5.js - If it doesn't open automatically, click this link: https://editor.p5js.org/
Now let's get this sketch started by creating our variables for our random colors!

For this sketch we will create our variables inside the curly braces ( {} ) for draw(). When you put variables inside the curly braces ( {} ) of a piece of code, they only work in there, nowhere else. So, for example, if you made some variables in setup(), you couldn't use them in draw().
If you wanted all the code to be able to use your variables, you'd put them up at the top, like you might have done in the previous activity. Then they'd be global variables!

Oh! One last thing I wanted to share with you before we create our variables. Our sketch will be using something called RGB color. This means that every color we use will be described by how much red, blue, and green is in it.
The numbers for red, green, and blue go from 0-255. For example, to create purple, you could set red to 255, green to 0, and blue to 255. That'd be a very bright purple!
Now, let's get those variables in. Start by creating a new line below background(220), and typing r = random(0, 100);
The random() function takes the 2 numbers you give it, and finds a random number between them. So, we told random() to pick a number between 0 and 100 for the variable r.
Now, let's get the other 2 variables we need. Make 2 new lines below the line with r on it, and type g = random(100, 200); and then type b = random(200, 255); on the third line.

Great work so far! Now, if we put all 3 of those variables together, we'll get a color with a decent amount of red, a large amount of blue, and a very large amount of green. Every time draw() runs, the color will change. Let's make a square so we can see it in action.

First, though, we need to set the color that we want our square to use. We'll use fill() - but this time, we need to tell it what color to use with our new variables. Make another new line below the line with b, and type fill(r, g, b); on it. It's that simple!
Next, make another new line below the fill line, and type rect(mouseX, mouseY, 20, 20); on that line. Then, you can press Play, and check out the colors!
Like the last actvity, we still have a black outline on our square, so let's change it! Do you remember what function we used to set the outline color last time?
Yep, stroke()! Make a new line between fill(... and rect(..., and type stroke(r, g, b); on it. Press Play and see what happens.

Now, the whole square is all one color, because we're using the same variables for the stroke() and the fill(). Every time draw() happens, it runs random() once for each of your variables - r, g, and b. Until draw() finishes, it won't run random() again, so the numbers will be the same every time you use them. That's why the inside and outside of the square are the same color, even though you're using r, g, and b twice!

Go ahead and take some time to experiment with your new creation! Maybe, you can change the ranges of random()? Just remember the colors have a 0-255 range. You could also create some new variables and give them different random() values, so you could create 2 fully random colors. Use one for the fill() and the other for the stroke() and see what you get!
